Solutions architect with Amazon web services take it away Ryan thanks Maya and thank you everyone for joining us
this morning and so my mention will start with just giving an overview of uh the security model for
AWS and our our security model is one of a shared responsibility and we look at
this in three different components uh so we look at both the infrastructure
security uh the security of the underlying services that uh you're running within AWS and then the
application security of the operating system the applications that that customers are running the first two of
those the infrastructure security and the security of the underlying services are all the responsibility of Amazon so
we're responsible for securing the physical security of our data centers uh the networking security uh all the way
up through the virtualization layer where the the responsibility gets handed off to the customer so everything up to
the operating system will be the responsibility of of Amazon to secure and then everything above uh the
hypervisor so starting at the operating system all the way up through the applications is uh going to be the
responsibility of the customer to secure and this is where our partner ecosystem provides a lot of value for our
customers in providing solutions that help them fulfill that part of their responsibility so I'm going to start now
and give an overview of how uh Amazon uh handles security for both our infrastructure and some of our services
and then uh Chris will give and will'll talk about the aerologic solution and how that helps customers secure their

obviously had quite a number of of large data centers that it it ran as well and and we have uh some some
consistent attributes across all of our uh data centers they're going to always be nondescript facilities you you'll
never see a big Amazon sign on one of our data centers we have very strong perimeter controls and we are very
strict uh controls over who gets physical access inside these data centers and and the the end of the day
you have to have a good business reason to be allowed into our data centers uh employees or customers that don't have a
valid business reason for being in the data centers if it's not part of your job essentially you're you're not going
to be permitted to to enter the data center uh any and all access to the data centers is audited and logged and those
those logs are reviewed and we also maintain uh some strict separation of duties for the people who do have access
to the data center and uh effectively if you have access to the physical data centers you're not allowed to have
logical access to the control plane or the systems that manage the data center and then conversely if you have logical
access to the control plane you're not allowed to have physical access to our data
centers one of the uh key tenants of security is also uh availability and we
design all of our data centers we call Contin availability so we don't have a Dr site right we don't do uh active
passive right all of our data centers are designed to be always on and always available and we we encourage our
customers to design their applications to be scalable and fault tolerant and leverage multiple data centers within a
region that we refer to those as availability zones all of our availability zones uh
in every region globally are all managed to the same exact standards and have the same exact audit scope as well they
always have very robust uh internet connectivity uh from multiple redundant
tier one providers as well as uh multiple redundancies for things like
power as well all of our configuration uh
management is done in a way that um will not impact end customers uh any changes
to our uh data center uh software uh is is done in such
a fashion that we don't have to take an entire data center offline right so you'll never see a maintenance window for for one of our regions or one of our
availability zones and any changes that we do uh employ are always going to be gone go
through a very rigorous change management uh process where the changes are reviewed logged tested and and uh

there's a small number of people who have access to these systems and they they have to authenticate using SSH key

manage all of the systems also come with what we call a security group it's a

um it acts as an inbound firewall in in VPC it's inbound and outbound and by

Integrity U maintaining the trustworthiness of the data that you're processing and the systems that process

goal is to block the attacks but uh you can't really ever completely block the attackers you can delay compromise but
you can never completely prevent it uh we think of uh prevention controls is primarily the shrinking the attack
surface shrinking the target if you will so that it takes longer and it's more
complicated for a committed adversary to breach you and then on the detection side that
becomes sort of the necessary uh uh partner in this is um you've invested in
the prevention controls to sort of hold off the attack um you now need to monitor the environment see when those
uh aggressive attempts are being made and be be in a position to take counter measures before it's too late or even if
you are compromised be able to contain that quickly and sometimes it's helpful to
refer back to a physical security analogy sometimes information security can get kind of abstract and so you if

it's important not only to have locks on the doors but an alarm system certainly a unattended lock unmonitored lock can

finally show up the next morning you need to pair those to to have uh effective
defense and that's really how we think about security and how we think about uh instrumenting our customers environments
and providing that layered defense is you start with actively monitored preventative controls to block the
attackers and slow them down you then add in the monitoring of the environment systems and applications to understand
what's actually going on and uh what attacker activity there is and then you

attack and so if you think about that in the context of AWS and the services they

the presses here so in terms of uh why why would I
say that web applications taxs are absolutely the most important thing and the first thing to focus on as you think about your uh AWS environment at least

um 86% of custom web apps contain SQL injection attacks that was from a study
by HP and in fact if 86% contain SQL injection uh I would suspect that that
they also contain other vulnerabilities since uh SQL injection is one of the most well understood and one of the

time so to dramatize this and talk about this a very very simple example of a SQL
injection attack we'll start with a shopping cart application as a sample
and hopefully your shopping cart's a little bit more uh visually appealing and sophisticated than this one but just
to to make the point uh here a consumer is looking for a coat and has selected a
fleece jacket the uh application is now going to produce two parameters a group
ID and an item id those get passed into the application so no harm so far just a
normal transaction where the harm comes in is if that that input isn't validated
uh a malicious person can inject a additional SQL statements in there in
this case to drop the table named products um certainly not something that you'd want to happen to your application
hopefully something that your application wouldn't allow um what we typically see is is that people are at
least somewhat aware of these type of attacks today but they may not have systematically implemented parameter

maybe a few places in there for uh the attacker to find that
opening so where web security manager enters in is it's effectively in a preventive control that sits in line it
sits behind the network firewall and in the case of AWS behind the security group configuration that you've implemented with the uh port and IP uh
restrictions um in the case of port and IP network firewall type of restrictions
the uh the I guess the limitation of that technology is that you know if you're operating a website you're
typically going to allow anyone access via ad0 and 443 so that you can conduct
business that's just a business requirement and the type of attack I just showed wouldn't be blocked uh and
couldn't be blocked by a network firewall without uh you know blocking your customers from accessing your
shopping cart in that case uh web security manager provides an additional layer of protection because it's
protocol aware it can be able to differentiate malicious traffic from legitimate traffic and only pass the
legitimate traffic to the web server so we'll talk a little bit about how that's done and it's really done through a
combination of uh factors it's done through negative security and positive security models on the negative security
side when you first install it it's going to filter out known attacks things like SQL injection are well recognized
patterns and in general can be blocked out of the box with a certain space set
of content um but that's generally not sufficient for uh an application um that
blocks the things that we know about today it doesn't restrict the the universe of things that could of attacks

model where you're saying deny everything except for these specific allowed things and the way that works in
a web application context is we uh go about learning learning the behavior of
the application learning what legitimate traffic is and then creating a model
where we screen everything else that out that doesn't fit that specific pattern that your application
requires and that's probably worth a little bit of explanation that's really a three-step process where the learning
engine that builds that positive security model analyzes application activity recommends a security policy
change and then that policy is validated by one of our web application Security
Experts and ultimately is approved by uh the customer um want to obviously Do no
harm in putting something in line so want to be conservative and run it through really three levels of
validation uh automatic Vol validation the human validation by one of our
analysts and then ultimately the customer validation and so in terms of the the
automatic validation and how that happens we start with the application in this case this show item
application it's going to look at the specific parameters and Abstract out in this case two parameters group and
item it's then going to look at the values for a given transaction in this case 10 and 45
34 and then it's going to start to build an inference about what legitimate inputs are in this case group appears to
be numeric and item appears to be numeric but that needs to be validated
based on large samples of data so uh we're going to look at transactions over
a period of time and literally thousands of transactions process that data in
batches and develop a high degree of confidence about what's normal for your given application and so this is in the
end the conclusion that can be drawn based on this sample set of
data so again again this conclusion that the learning engine Drew was that group inputs are always numeric and that the
vast majority of time item input certain numeric and so that'll end up becoming the recommended policy that'll then go
through the validation and approval process I
described and what's really critical is the Nuance associated with this so it it
can't just be a very simple dumb process where um you build a list effectively so
if you allow commas then the question should be asked of do you allow other punctuation another example would be SQL
injection is often going to use a single quote as uh in its syntax using a single
quote is the only mechanism by which you identify SQL uh um injection is a really
poor practice because if you have Hy uh if you have a customer specifically in

to be some judgment uh applied both within the automated learning mechanism as well as by the analyst to be able to
uh ensure that uh you're you're building an effective
policy and so once that policy is built then it needs to be validated across uh
again more traffic to be able to identify whether that in fact is effective or whether it has unintended

able to uh shrink that attack surface dramatically and thus make your
